                <div class="header">
                    <h1>2012 Detroit Auto Show electric vehicle preview</h1>
                </div>
                <div class="content">
                   <img  id="Phoenix_Image_ctl00_ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_idMainImage" alt="" src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-main.jpg" />
                   
                   
                   

                   
                   <div>
                       <h2>Our rundown of the hottest plug-in cars at the forthcoming NAIAS 2012</h2>
                       <div class="info">
                        By Gavin Conway on December 28, 2011 5:14 PM<br />
                       </div>
                        
                       <p><strong>Aside from the usual gas-guzzling 4x4s, pickups and turbo-charged sedans (sorry, saloons), January’s 2012 North American International Auto Show in Detroit will also be flooded with hybrids from the likes of BMW, Mercedes, Acura, Honda and Volkswagen. That’s all taking us in the right direction, but unless it comes with a plug, we’re not going to spend too much time dwelling on it here.</strong></p><p>So we’ve prepared a little pre-show teaser of some of the EVs coming to Detroit to whet your appetite. But crucially, make sure you check in with us nearer the January 9th launch of the show for even more detailed news of what’s coming. </p><p><strong>Amp Electric Vehicles</strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-amp.jpg"/></p><p>American EV conversion company Amp will bring an electric Jeep Grand Cherokee to the Detroit auto show, and is expected to release final pricing and introduce its first dealer. Steve Burns, president of Amp, says it will be price-competitive with the Tesla Model S, an electric sedan that in base form is priced from $57,400 before a $7,500 federal tax credit. However, the 37-kilowatt-hour battery pack gives the vehicle a range of approximately 100 miles, so it’s not got the Model S’s range to match the price. Still, as an urban status symbol it could work.</p><p><strong><strong>BMW</strong></strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-bmw-i8.jpg"/></p><p>The i3 concept heralds the upcoming pure-electric small hatchback BMW, which we should see in production form by 2013. Likewise, the i8 is the company’s plug-in hybrid supercar, also due out in 2013. Both have been familiar motorshow attendees throughout 2011, and are likely to make it to Detroit, too. </p><p>The fresher news, BMW tells us, is the 5-Series ActiveHybrid 5, which marries a turbocharged straight-six petrol engine with a 54hp electric motor for a system output of 340hp. That delivers 0-62mph in 5.9secs and a combined fuel consumption of up to 44.1mpg. It’s on sale in the UK early 2012.</p><p><strong><strong>Ford </strong></strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-ford.jpg"/></p><p>It’s a pretty safe bet that as the launch of the pure-electric Focus gets ever closer, there will be examples on hand for Detroit – Ford recently claimed that the Focus EV will earn a rating of more than100MPGe, which betters the Nissan LEAF. Also likely to make an appearance will be the C-Max Hybrid and Plug-in Hybrid (which will be badged ‘Energi’). The C-Max is a mid-sized people carrier that in standard guise can seat five people. No word yet on pure-electric range or speed.</p><p><strong><strong>Nissan</strong></strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-nissan-nv200-electric.jpg"/></p><p>Nissan is likely to pitch up in Detroit with its NV200 pure-electric van. The van, which is actually being trialled in London, uses the same powertrain as the Nissan LEAF. Earlier this year, the Japan Post Service ran an NV200 EV on routine delivery and collection duties in Japan, and New York City will be testing six electric versions of the NV200. </p><p>We’re guessing that the van – especially when loaded for business – will be considerably heavier than the LEAF, so performance and range aren’t likely to match the car’s. There’s no official word on what the range of the NV200 is, but in full-on delivery mode, we’d guess at 60-70 miles. There is, though, the option of using a Quick Charger to get a charge up to 80% capacity in half an hour, which will greatly improve the van’s practicality.</p><p><strong><strong>Smart</strong></strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-smart.jpg"/></p><p>Smart’s “tongue-in-cheek” for-us pickup takes the popular fortwo shape, stretches it and adds a flatbed to the back. The 900mm loadspace isn’t huge but it’s enough to carry two of Smart’s high-tech electric pushbikes (the eBike). And electric motor provides the power – 75 horsepower is up on the fortwo electric drive we tested early in 2011. Maximum speed is around 75mph, so it’s still only designed as an urban and suburban runabout rather than a serious long-distance hauler. </p><p><strong><strong>Tesla</strong></strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-tesla.jpg"/></p><p>The creator of the pure electric Roadster supercar next year’s stunning Model S sedan will set up its booth (‘stand’ to UK folk) to look like one of its new high street stores, and will showcase its high-tech manufacturing prowess. The company’s aim is to show that it is not only building a cutting-edge car, but is also pioneering innovative manufacturing. Judging by our tour of its vast factory in Palo Alto, California, they’ve put their money where their mouth is.</p><p><strong><strong>Toyota</strong></strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-toyota.jpg"/></p><p>Toyota released a coy little image of its NS4 concept car earlier in December, ahead of its expected unveiling at the Detroit show. The company’s not saying much about the car, except that it’s an “advanced plug-in hybrid”. Given that scrap of info, we reckon it could use a drivetrain like the one that’ll power the upcoming Toyota Prius Plug-in, a five-door hatch the can go 14 miles in pure-electric mode and has an equivalent combined fuel economy of 134.5mpg. And the concept’s fetching headlight detail suggests a vehicle with much more sex appeal than the worthy-but-dull Prius. </p><p><strong><strong>Via Motors</strong></strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-via.jpg"/></p><p>Bob Lutz, former vice chairman of General Motors and father of the Chevy Volt extended range electric car, will introduce the world’s first EREV pickup truck, SUV and van at Detroit. They’re to be made by Via Motors, at which Lutz is now a board member. Via COO Alan Perriton says the electric drive system means their utility vehicles deliver the power and performance of a V8, with better fuel economy than many smaller cars.</p><p><strong><strong>Volkswagen</strong></strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-vw.jpg"/></p><p>Along with a pure-electric concept car, VW will also bring its Jetta petrol-electric hybrid to Detroit. The Jetta’s 1.4-litre petrol engine will be joined by a lithium ion battery pack – the target is 44mpg overall. The pure-electric concept – not to be confused with the small E-Up concept we saw at the Frankfurt show in 2009 – will borrow some of the style cues from the latest Beetle, but we are assured that it definitely is not an electric version of the Bug. </p><p><strong><strong>Volvo </strong></strong></p><p><img  src="http://www.thechargingpoint.com/SiteMedia/images/detroit-2012-preview-embed-volvo.jpg"/></p><p>We’re expecting Volvo to set out its plans for plug-in hybrids at the Detroit motor show. The company has already announced details of its V60 Plug-in Hybrid, which it claims is the world’s first diesel-electric hybrid. Volvo has also confirmed that the U.S. will get a plug-in hybrid, but that it will be petrol-electric as opposed to European diesel-electric offering. The U.S. version is also unlikely to be based on the V60 estate – expect either the S60 saloon or XC60 crossover to do the honours. </p><p>The V60 Plug-in goes on sale in the UK early in 2012 and will cost an estimated £47,000 before the Plug-In Car Grant, which at the moment would reduce the cost by £5,000 – so that’s £42,000. The V60 uses a five-cylinder 2.4-litre diesel to power the front wheels through a six-speed automatic gearbox, with a 70hp electric motor driving the rear wheels. The 11.2kWh lithium ion battery is installed under the boot floor. The official NEDC figure for fuel consumption stands at 149mpg.</p> 
                   </div>
